Plot a Code Co-occurrence Network

Source: R/map_cooccur_matrix.R
map_cooccur_matrix.Rd

This function takes a code co-occurrence matrix (e.g., from create_cooccur_matrix()) and produces a network visualization using igraph and ggraph. Edges represent co-occurrence counts (within transcripts or documents), and node sizes reflect the number of transcripts in which each code appears.

Usage

map_cooccur_matrix(
  coccur_matrix,
  edge_min = 10,
  layout = "circle",
  edge_color_low = "lightgray",
  edge_color_high = "purple",
  node_color = "lightblue"
)

Arguments

coccur_matrix

A square co-occurrence matrix (numeric matrix or data frame) where rows and columns represent codes, and diagonal entries indicate the number of transcripts in which each code appears.

edge_min

Minimum edge weight (co-occurrence count) to retain in the network. Edges with lower weights are removed. Default is 10.

layout

Layout algorithm for node placement. Passed to ggraph::ggraph(). Common options are "circle", "fr" (Fruchterman–Reingold), or "kk" (Kamada–Kawai). Default is "circle".

edge_color_low

Color for weakest edges. Default is "lightgray".

edge_color_high

Color for strongest edges. Default is "purple".

node_color

Color for nodes. Default is "lightblue".

Value

A ggplot2 object containing the network visualization. Can be further customized with standard ggplot2 functions.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Suppose 'excerpts' is your dataset of coded transcripts
coccur_df <- create_cooccur_matrix(excerpts, output = "data.frame")

# Plot network with minimum edge weight of 10
map_cooccur_matrix(coccur_df, edge_min = 10)

# Use a force-directed layout instead of circle
map_cooccur_matrix(coccur_df, edge_min = 5, layout = "fr")
} # }
